The old village had some ancient sights.
The walls were completely covered in moss.
As were the graves in the area.
Some of the bricks were more moss than brick.
We even saw an ancient gravestone while we were there.
In the ancient cemetery, the dead don't speak but the moss tells a story of slow, calm life.
It covers the headstones of villagers past, clinging to the engraved letters.
The moss makes a soft carpet on the hard, ancient stones, like a welcome mat to this foreboding place.
Wherever it can find a shady spot, it thrives, like on the corners of this ancient staircase.
The moss has no preference for who's graves it covers, and does not care how Maria died.
There are many sacred places left from thousands of years ago all over the earth.
Many of these sacred places are very unusually shaped and have a strange look.
Some of these sacred places from our past appear to similar to tomb stones or monuments of more previous years.
Some of the sacred sites are more modern in that they show signs of skilled labor like block laying and the mixing of concrete. They also may have been painted.
At many of these sights artifacts have been found which contain writing and are made of silver and gold. This appears to be more modern.
I've heard ancient stories of secret passages through these mossy rock areas.
Some old writing within the moss, maybe it's a clue or code to enter.
The clue told me to push the green brick to enter a special chamber.
I pushed the brick and it opened to these old mossy stairs, i'll follow them.
It lead me to this sacred burial ground, it's full of treasures and wealth beyond your imagination.

The office was in need of a better storage solution than what we had.
Cubicles formed by stacks of manila envelopes was less than ideal for the workers.
After a delay, the logistics guy finally showed up.
For a while he fiddled with a silly metal basket solution.
Eventually, he sorted everything out using a filling cabinet.
They prepared to get all of the files into the database.
First they pulled out all of the folders from the cabinets.
Then they stacked them up and got them ready to be entered.
After that, they began entering data into the database.
When they were done, they had no files left to enter.
Mrs. Jones had to organize.
The students gave her hand.
They spent hours working and time flew.
Joe was the last to leave.
Everything was neat and tidy afterwards!
Joan was working hard.
Everyone at the office was ready to work.
Their day was just beginning.
John stopped by to help do some work.
He was in charge of organizing the folders.

We kept at it all day, going through the files, making stacks, and organizing.

From far away the ferris wheel looked simply incredible.
Even though the first color scheme was impressive, as our boat drew closer it displayed an even cooler color scheme.
As the boat rounded the harbor I was able to get a full shot of all of the buildings, their surfaces lite up now from street lights.
As we were leaving the harbor once more the ferris wheel turned a welcoming blue color, as if to make my depressed mood as it faded away.
I said goodbye to the lovely peer, our ferry now chugging on into the night.

Chuck is a squirrel who spends his days running through the landscape, looking for nuts.
One day, Chuck heard a loud noise and decided to observe from a hidden spot.
He saw a train lumber by slowly.
After the train passed, Chuck continued ambling along without a care in the world.
"Look," he said to himself, "I think I'm going to climb that tree."
The squirrel waited at the side of the road for the opportune moment to cross,
so that he could get back to his little whole on the side of the canyon.
He had to wait for the train to come through though,
so that he could safely make it back
to his home on the canyon.

This is Chad and Jeremy. Chad sings and Jeremy plays guitar.
Chad is an awesome singer but that wasn't enough. He wanted to play guitar like Jeremy but his fingers were too stubby.
This ate away at Chad. One day during a church gig he got on his knees and prayed that God would let him play guitar even better than Jeremy.
An angel appeared to Chad and said there were too many guitar players. The world needs adequate trombone players Chad.

Suddenly Chad felt impelled to grab a trombone and squeak out a tune. He was so happy. Until he tried to put it down. The angel had forgotten to say the release trombone prayer. So now Chad and his instrument are stuck together for eternity.

The Ottawa Dragon Boat Festival is a yearly event that attracts 5,500 paddlers and over 70,000 spectators in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada.
Since its inception in 1993, thousands of participants have gathered at Mooney's Bay Park on Riverside Drive in Ottawa to race. Admission to the festival is free to spectators.
The competition is fierce. Many accompanying family and friends also make the trip to show their support and honour survivors.
The dragon race challenge is actually a charity and has till date raised over $3 million.

Sue was washing the pots and pans when she realized the water was cold.
She turn on the hot water and the water got warmer.
Soon the water was hot so she continued what she was doing.
Top part is clean, now for the bottom.
All done except to turn the water off and dry the pan.
I had to wash the pan today.
I really didn't want to but I had put it off forever.
I took the pan and placed it in the sink and ran some water over it.
I turned it over so the bottom could get wet too.
Then I placed it into the sink and left the water running over it.
Dishes isn't always a fun process,
but it has to be done.
You have to wash the inside of the pan,
and don't forget to wash the outside.
Then of course, make sure to wash the lid, so that the pan and the lid can be safely used next time you are cooking.

Anna went to visit a church on her vacation.
She didn't know what this monkey was supposed to represent, but she thought it was funny.
She thought the church was so beautiful she wanted a picture with it.
Outside the church she decided to take a selfie
Later she saw a statue that looked like her and took a picture with it.
The dark church was creepy in the lingering light.
The carvings in the wood shone strangely.
A girl asked her friend to take her picture in the dimly lit church.
Her friend then took a selfie before getting creeped out.
They ran outside- it was much safer there.
I love visiting this old church, it helps me relax and I love the beautiful windows,
This is one of my favorite pieces in the church, it makes me happy to see it.
I met a random girl while I was relaxing in the church, she seems to like me.
She got too close for comfort and tried to kiss me, not in my church! ew
I told her I was not interested in her at all and ditched her by a statue outside the church.
The day was gloomy and the stained glass was made darker by the lack of light from the Sun.
I realized, I must use my camera on my cellphone so I could later identify the statues.
I was alone, but I could feel that I was being watched.
But always ready and willing for a selfie. Maybe, they might think I'm a tourist.
Finally, I compared the statues. Damn! They don't match. My search continues.

I have always lived inland during my younger years and have a yearning for the sea now and I am fascinated by cottage style communities close to the ocean side.

They arrived at the old building early in the morning.

This dome of brick could not have been easy to build.
The broken arch was amazing.
History surrounds this stone entrance way.
The rock quarry has trucks running through it.
The castle stands after decades of time passed by.
The openings are splendid works of masonry.
Wear and tear over the years is evident between the stone walls.
I went to go see a large cathedral.
The ceilings were so high and unbelievably tall.
The seats and stage were extravagant and fit so many people.
There was a large statue in the church, and it represented their God.
There was also an inscription below various statues.
The cathedral looms over the town. It's Gothic architecture giving it the appearance of a screaming man.
Inside though are lofty ceilings, brightly painted in white and filled with graceful arches.
Light, pillars, and graceful curves are designed to bring the eyes to the center.
Statues grace the halls, giving those that pass through their blessings.
All is not cheerful inside, though. There are reminders of darker times.

Hank was starting some home repairs that he's put off for too long.

He took a real close look and realized his mistake.

The man climbs the ladder. He then gets the silicone gun ready.
First he loads the tube of silicone into the silicone gun.
Then he turns the handle of the gun until it tightens against the tube.
Then he uses the silicone gun to apply the silicone to the wood door frame.
Once he has put the silicone on the door frame, he then attaches the door frame to the door.

On the last day of our vacation we decided to visit rock mountain.
There were a lot of beautiful mountains.
We noticed as we got there there were workers doing work.
One worker was carrying a huge rock.
He told us part of the park was closed due to the construction so we ended up leaving.
During our stay we visited a beautiful cannon. The pathways leading to the cannon were edged with rocks hammered from the cannon.
The cannon itself was huge and seemed never-ending.
We then got to see some men hammering the boulders into usable pieces for, I imagine, the pathways.
The workers seemed very happy.
On the pathway out we could see their current progress.
Our project began in a far-off, inaccessible but very beautiful locale.
I gathered with other volunteers to use nearby loose rocks to rebuild and fortify existing roads and structures.
Rocks were brought in by backhoe and truck for our use.
That's me in the middle as we began our work with the rocks.
There will be an inscription on that rock describing our mission and from there, the entire valley can be seen.
Out trip to the canyon provided us with so many amazing views.
There was much more to do there than just look at the views.

This is an old steel industrial town.
There are not that may people who live in this town.
There is plenty work here.
There are also very beautiful structures.
There are also some really cool restaurants here.
Some people don't see any beauty in an industrial city.
They say the street are bleak, and the cloud of pollution always hangs over everything.
The area under the overpass doesn't hold any magic for them.
But they don't see the gorgeous bridge at the edge of town, or the lovely arches at the start of the bridge.
When my family gets together in my gritty hometown, we all celebrate the hidden beauties the town contains.
Refinery is the main business in this town.
People may complain about the oil business -- about its hazards -- but this town and this people survive because of the oil business.
Miles and miles of flat open space. Thank God there is wealth hidden beneath the earth.
We have learned to live in spite of polluted water. You get accustomed to the smell, and drink bottled water.
We have a quiet social life. Nothing fancy. The oil business has too many fluctuations to build something fancy.

I was out driving yesterday and I got stuck in traffic because of a huge accident.
The whole road was blocked off while they cleaned it up.
They had all kinds of equipment there to move debris.
We were all stuck there for hours until they were able to clear enough of the debris to let traffic flow.
Eventually everything was cleared out of the way and normal traffic resumed.
The team was called in to the scene, ambulance having already extracted most of the passengers.
A train had been overturned, and it was our job to get it back to work.
Our machines were there in a few moments, and it took us a while to move everything.
Soon, it was night, and we had to cordon off the area.
Before long, we managed to have the train cars loaded on this truck, and ready to be sent away, job well done.
The emergency workers responded to a call at a highway construction site.
Traffic was mostly unaffected by the accident.
The construction workers were forced to move their vehicles off the road.
The work continued into the early night.
The damaged vehicle was not still not removed at this point.
We were stuck in traffic due to this wreck on the road.
We were stuck so long we hiked up here to take a photo of the wreck.
Finally they got machines in to move the wreck.
After they cleaned the road they let us through.
But the truck that wrecked was still off to the side.

We saw the early vestiges of sunlight from inside the cave, and it made us feel a little less forlorn.

Having to hunker down in the cave for the night, having lost our bearings on our way out last night, made us feel hopeless. But being able to see the beautiful mountains, what we had came here for, restored our spirits.
We followed the river for some time, remembering that our house was downstream.
And we found it! It wasn't very long at all.
We had to bring the trip to a close soon, we had nearly missed the expedition home with the cave incident, but it made us feel that much closer as a group, as people; as friends.
